Dear Young Talent,
 
If you’re reading this, it’s because you want to be great.

You desire mastery.
 
But the challenges in your life are not yet hard enough.
 
This is a problem.

Whether you realize it or not, you are in a crisis.
 
You have two options.

Take the blue pill

Continue the life you’ve known. Get paid a nice salary in a cushy office. Live easy.
 
Take the red pill

This is the reality pill. It asks you to think about how great you could be if you realized your potential.

This is the road less traveled.

— — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — — —

How great do you want to be for your community? For your family?

How great do you want to be for yourself?
 
Asking these questions is hard.
 
It is hard to believe in something that may be unpopular.
 
It is hard to admit that it is your choice to make an impact.
 
It is hard to try and risk failing.
 
But I promise you this.
 
If you stick with it, if you persevere,

then you will find a deeper, more satisfying meaning to life than you ever imagined.
 
If you don’t want this. Stop reading now.

The #1 thing to develop to become better

Grow an internal standard so strong that you are obsessed with achieving it.

The greatest men and women you will ever meet have a strong internal bar of quality.
 
It allows them to consistently surpass expectations.

The bar says, “THIS can be BETTER. I can be BETTER. MY COMMUNITY deserves MORE.”

This internal bar is created over time.

It is created by consistent exposure to your role models.

You don’t need to be born with the bar. You can grow it.

Your internal bar is the result of your repeat influences.
 
In this way it can be trained and shaped and forged.

After that it can withstand the scrutiny of the world.

Don’t work for this company

Don’t work for a company where you are the top contributor.

If the people you work with don’t challenge you to be better, than you will not become better.

Don’t work for a company that lacks diversity.

One of the most overlooked truths on the planet is that different perspectives combined thoughtfully lead to superior results. Work for a company that has decisions makers that come from local as well as international folks, men as well as women. Rich and poor.

People with uncommon backgrounds will deepen your perspective.

Don’t work for a company where your ideas don’t matter.

If you are in a company where junior employees have no say, leave. The best companies and leaders realize that valuable insights come from everywhere -especially those working on the front line.

If you cannot play a role in making decisions, you will not gain a broad perspective. This is necessary to make an impact in any business. Make sure you can contribute to decisions that impact design, product, and engineering.

Don’t work for a company where you are not challenged to be better. Every. Day.

The best engineers engage their curiosity everyday. Don’t just plug libraries and APIs together. Understand how the libraries are built. Is there a better way to build it?

Don’t work for an outsourcing company.

If you work for an outsourcing company, your skills will plateau quickly. You will not learn new technologies at scale. You will not have the ability to make product decisions. And you will not be prepared to build a company. You will become a worse engineer.

Truths all young talents should know

If you want to be great. Listen.

Where you work matters less than the people you’re with

Traveling does not make you a better person. It just shows you who you are.

If you are a rude, inconsiderate person in Australia, you’re likely to be that same rude person in France.

It is the same with self mastery.
 
Traveling to Singapore or Australia does not, by itself, make you better.

The purpose, intention, and action of getting better is what makes it so.
 
Mastery is consistent effort.
 
Do not rate your expertise based on where you work.

Rate your growth by how fast you are learning.
 
How often were you challenged this week?
 
How have you grown from the past month?
 
You will only reach your highest potential by working with people that are better than you.
 
This is why the fastest sprinters on earth train together. They know they can only reach their highest level by working with the best. If you want to go to the olympics, train with olympic athletes.
 
Doing the opposite — working with people that are not as good as you — will reduce what you can become.

“As human beings, our greatness lies not so much in being able to remake the world — that is the myth of the atomic age — as in being able to remake ourselves.” — Mahatma Ghandi

You can start working with the best now. Wherever you are.
 
As recently as the 1990s and early 2000s it was true that remote work produced inferior results. Collaboration was too difficult.
 
How far you lived from another person determined who you would become friends with.
 
And who you would fall in love with.
 
And who you will work with.
 
But this is no longer true!
 
Your mentor doesn’t have to be in the same city as you. They just need to care that you get better.

Join an open source project now. Extend a repo.
 
Don’t follow blindly. Move your life with intention.
 
I had a conversation with my co-founder a few days ago about acting for short term gain vs. long term gain. He called these “finite” and “infinite” games respectively.
 
A “game” is a collection of tactics to achieve a goal.
 
Some of the games we play are extremely fleeting — like going out for a night of heavy drinking or eating a jelly donut. The success of “winning” doesn’t last long and can often damage the longer games we’re playing.
 
The closest thing that we have to an infinite game is life.
 
Do you eat healthy?
 
Do you exercise?
 
When is the last time you told the people you love how you feel?

The Only Game That Wins

The only game that wins is the long game.

This longer game nicely describes the way Warren Buffet, one of the wealthiest individuals on the planet, plays a different game from everyone else.
 
When Buffet purchases a company, he intends to hold it.
 
But this is only part of the picture.

Being a public company means you have to answer to shareholders that focus on short term earnings. This is ironic because great CEOs succeed through strategies that compound over years and decades.

Buffett is widely considered to be the best investor in the world. The company he controls, Berkshire Hathaway, often purchases companies that are public and makes them (effectively) private.

This is why a Buffet acquisition can be so powerful.

He takes some pressure off short term results. This allows Buffet’s companies to make investments that return years later. They can increase inventory. They can take advantage of the environmental limitations public companies suffer from.

Play the infinite game. Play for life.
 
In the case of your career, your success depends entirely on your daily actions that make you better for tomorrow.

Don’t get caught up playing the short game:

The short game comes from doing things that matter now. But make little impact on the meaning of your life.

Buying material things.

Working at a company that isn’t challenging and doesn’t allow growth just because it offers a high salary, or a nice office.

To play the longer game you must focus on where you want to be in the future and take consistent steps to get there.

Sacrifice income for mastery.

Work with people that make you feel like you’re not good enough.

Maintain a healthy lifestyle.

How you get there

Change I want to I must.

If you must do something. Than you will die before you fail.

Imaging that you must will help you to refuse to compromise your progress.

Work with the best people in the world

You can’t start working at Facebook, Google, AirBnB, or Stripe yet. You don’t know the culture. You may not have the experience.

But you can make your own path.

Work for the startup filled with talent that could work anywhere in the world but decides to work for themselves. Work the person that could be the next Steve Jobs — that already has the experience of the big company but has decided to create something that pushes the boundaries of what is possible.

Be hungry to learn

“Not only keep up with trends in your own discipline, but also in adjacent disciplines. Engineering disciplines cross pollinate each other more than ever before and being on top of that gives you a strong edge in your career growth.” — Venu Venugopal, VP of Product Management and Engineering, Knovel

You can succeed.

The only thing that separates you from greatness is being around the right people and working hard.

Don’t settle. Be the person you must be.
